On New Year's Eve, Radio-Canada presents a live comedy special, ''[[Bye Bye (TV series)|Bye Bye]]'', which features musical and comedy guests, performing live. ===Children=== Children's programming airs in the morning and feature animated series such as ''[[Kim Possible]]'', ''[[The Smurfs|Les Schtroumps]]'', ''[[Lizzie McGuire]]'' and ''La cour de rÃ©cre'' amongst Quebec-produced shows such as ''La vie selon Annie''. For example '''''Zeste''''' broadcasts on stations in the Western provinces on Saturday early evenings, while '''''Luc et Luc''''' airs Sunday evenings in the Maritimes. ==Stations and affiliates== {{See also|List of Radio-Canada television stations}} Of Canada's three major French-language television networks, Radio-Canada is the only one that broadcasts terrestrially in all Canadian provinces. With the exception of [[Atlantic Canada]], where a single station serves all four provinces through an extensive network of rebroadcasters, the network has at least one originating station in every province. These stations serve every major market in French and English Canada, with privately owned [[affiliate]]s serving smaller markets in Quebec. Unlike CBC Television affiliates, which often have several alternative programming sources, Radio-Canada affiliates are effectively constrained to carry network programming throughout the day in pattern with no preemptions. The only exceptions are for local and regional programming and commercials. By the end of the year, TQS had filed for bankruptcy; as part of exiting bankruptcy, a deal was announced the following spring for Radio-Canada to directly acquire the stations.[http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2008/n2008-5.htm#2 CRTC Application 2008-0516-1] The transaction was approved by the CRTC on June 26, 2008.[http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2008/db2008-130.htm CRTC Decision 2008-130] Only the stations in [[Rouyn-Noranda]] and [[RiviÃ¨re-du-Loup]] remain as private affiliates, rather than [[owned-and-operated station|O&Os]].
